Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Medium: Signal representation, sampling and recovery on graphs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Datasets that are collected in physical and engineering applications, as well as social, biomolecular, commercial, security, and many other domains, are becoming larger and more complex. In many cases, such data is analyzed manually or using methods that extract only superficial information and can lead to subjective and non-reproducible conclusions. There is thus an urgent need for the development of methodologies that formalize analysis of complex data. Graphs provide a natural formalism to capture complex interactions that govern the structure of the data in many applications. However, a rigorous framework for signal and data processing on graphs has been lacking. This proposal aims to develop the fundamentals of signal representation, sampling and recovery on graphs.

Signal and data processing has been the focus of the principal investigators? work for many years. In this project, the team will develop a mathematically rigorous framework for signal processing on graphs that offers a new paradigm for the analysis of high-dimensional data with complex, non-regular structure. By extending fundamental signal processing concepts such as filtering, Fourier and wavelet analysis to data residing on general graphs, the framework will offer principled solutions to a number of data analysis problems, such as data compression, recovery, localization, detection, and others. Specifically, the team will 1) develop efficient succinct representations for signals on graphs, 2) design efficient strategies that leverage the graph structure for sampling signals on graphs, and 3) develop near-optimal and computationally efficient estimators for recovering graph signals from samples.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project was to develop the fundamentals of signal representation, sampling, and recovery on graphs.

 

Datasets that are collected in physical and engineering applications, as well as social, biomolecular, commercial, security, and many other domains, are becoming larger and more complex. In many cases, this data is analyzed manually or using ad-hoc methods that extract only superficial information and can lead to subjective and nonreproducible conclusions. There is thus an urgent need for the development of methodologies that formalize analysis of complex data.

 

Signal and data processing has been the focus of the team?s work for many years. Recently, the emerging framework of signal processing on graphs has offered a new paradigm for the analysis of high-dimensional data with complex, nonregular structure. The theory extends fundamental signal processing concepts, including signals, filters, Fourier transform, frequency response, low- and high-pass filtering, from signals residing on regular lattices, which are studied by the classical signal processing theory, to data residing on general graphs. Furthermore, signal processing on graphs formulates and offers solutions to a number of data analysis problems, such as data compression, recovery, localization, detection, and many others.

 

The team pursued the above-stated goal by tackling the following questions: How do we properly represent signals on graphs? How do we properly sample signals on graphs? How do we properly recover signals on graphs? As a result, a number of novel results came about within signal sampling and recovery on graphs, signal representations on graphs, signal detection on graphs, edge sampling in graphs, multi-armed bandits by sampling transfer graphs, signal quantization and recovery on graphs, graph convolution for deep reinforcement learning, active learning for graph neural network, non-convex optimization over graphs, graph trend filtering, application of graph sampling to lightweight structure design, graph signal processing with applications to urban data analysis and graph-based tangent plane estimation for 3D point cloud denoising.

 

This highly interdisciplinary project involved researchers from disparate fields of signal processing, mathematics, statistics, computer science, material science, medicine and civil engineering. As a result, all students in these areas got exposed and learned about the others, creating more well-rounded professionals.
